Master Li Zhonggong and Master Zhu Fanyuan were still his teachers. He traveled to Yan and Zhao with his accumulated learning, yet ultimately found no kindred spirits, and so journeyed through Wu and Chu before returning to settle. Before long, the realm was thrown into turmoil, and heroes arose on all sides. Those who usurped power and seized titles, hearing of his reputation, sought to recruit him, but he withdrew in seclusion and refused to bend. His hardships and loyal indignation were all expressed in his poetry, while his spirit remained as bold and unyielding as ever.

At the founding of our dynasty, when the realm was first pacified, he was among the first recluses summoned to the capital. He was appointed magistrate of Jiading Prefecture, and upon completing his term, was permitted to retire due to age. He then returned home, journeying along the Yi, Wu, Yue, Huai, and Xiang rivers. In his later years, he built a retreat among the fields and forests, secluding himself to teach at home, and his poetry grew ever more refined. Once, when dozens of the prefecture’s people were falsely implicated in a fabricated disaster, Master Zhang exonerated them and secured their safety—a deed for which the people still hold him in gratitude.

His poetry, in form and spirit, drew from the *Airs* and *Elegantiae*, while deeply immersing itself in the styles of the Han, Wei, and Six Dynasties. As for the poets of the High Tang and the early Yuan, he did not deign to mention them. His bearing was lofty and imposing, his appearance striking, and thus his words and thoughts flowed with divine swiftness, as if preordained. He did not rely on exhaustive search or labored thought, yet achieved a grandeur both profound and enduring—like the boundless clouds of the vaulted heavens or the ceaseless waves of the Yangtze—immeasurable and beyond tracing. This is why those of shallow talent and narrow vision could never attain his heights. His renown among princes, scholars, and officials was thus well-earned.

Alas, much of his lifetime’s writings was lost amid the ravages of war, with only fragments remaining. Master Lu once gathered what he could—perhaps one or two hundred pieces—intending to preserve them in print. Before the task was complete, he passed away, and the collection was again scattered, with little surviving. Those who cherished his work could not bear to discard it, and so I have transcribed a tenth of it, most of which aligns with the selections in *Dazhuang’s* compilation.

Though I once studied under Master Zhang and failed to live up to his teachings, how dare I presume to compose this account? Yet his learning was vast, his words eloquent, and his literary brilliance unmatched in his time. His great virtue and towering reputation were already evident in his deeds, and his legacy, though dimmed, shall not fade into oblivion.

My elder brother *Dazhuang*, diligent in study and devoted to righteousness, will surely carry on Master Lu’s aspirations with ease—how could he not delight in upholding the Way of literature?

The Master’s personal name was *Shuai*, his courtesy name *Mengxun*, and his sobriquet *Danmo*. His disciples referred to him as *Master Danmo*.

**Zong Lian’s Preface**

My friend, Master Ni Zizheng, in his youth studied under our late teacher, Master Xia, and later received the teachings of Master Lu’s *benxin* doctrine from Master Peng Mengyue. His conduct was steadfast and sincere, earning the trust of his community—even the humble and unlearned recognized him as a gentleman. Though he lived in poverty in a humble lane, he remained self-disciplined, cautious in his associations, and sparing in speech. He never ceased seeking instruction from teachers and friends, and his demeanor was always marked by humility. Afflicted by chronic illness, he seldom wrote, but when compelled to compose, he grounded his work in the classics, ensuring its purity and correctness.

I once heard the teachings of *xingli* from Master Peng, and in our discussions and refinements, Master Ni was my greatest aid. For over a decade, our bond remained as close as a single day. In a certain year, he was recommended for office and appointed instructor of Xinjian, returning home twice during his tenure. There, we delved into the words and deeds of ancient sages and worthies, finding solace in the quiet of overgrown groves, crumbling pavilions, lamplight, and moonlit ponds. His spirit was rich and sincere, rivaling that of the ancients.

In the spring of the seventeenth year of *Hongwu*, he traveled to the capital after mourning his parents, but succumbed to a minor illness and passed away. Overcome with grief, I urged his son, Heng, to preserve his father’s writings. Four years later...

During the late Yuan dynasty, poets of neighboring prefectures who gained fame—such as Zhang Zhongju, Huang Junrui, and Wei Dapu—all engaged with him as peers.

chunks.original_text: 衡持文若干篇，日《宗濂叶》，请曰：先君居新建时，县庠乃元江丞相宗濂书．院也，故药以是名。 先君托知之深，莫公若也，愿叙其端。 余不获辞，读之再而感曰：夫士之为学，求足於人者多，求足於身者寡矣。 君育天地之和，山川之秀．，蒙先世之泽，质淳气清，性行端洁，自非庸儒俗生所能至。 内既足於身，而外亦无待乎人者也。 故其言论风旨，一本诸简易之理，精微之得道，不待究而自明，诚不俟立而自着，是所以得之本心也欤。 宜其施诸事为，训诸讲解，举不论於口耳之习，言辞之辨，一存乎端本诚身而已矣。 本端身诚，则圣人之道，经世之法具矣，尚何俟其繁赘也哉。 其策问、讲义、叙说，皆发乎正大之要，存养之方。 陆门之杨、钱，殆不是过也。 其诗歌篇什，得乎性情之实，而韦、孟之闲雅，陶、柳之冲澹有焉。 惜未之大用，无以发其和粹之蓄，岂圣代之可多见也乎。 今凡新建学徒，在当时尝闻其言者尤有立，是岂＇其涵濡操励之工为少哉。 惜其学本诸陆，而世之宗朱者，或有不与焉，是故其特立不惑，宜世之鲜知也矣。 然究其会，同其言，可得而竟泯泯者乎。 使其传之不替，岂不羽翼乎周、程、朱、陆之言，必矣。 墓则友人昊君伯宗为之铭，惜余无足以发之。 姑以义弗辞，叙其桑焉。 云溪诗集叙 孟子之言曰：王者之迹熄而诗亡，诗亡然后春秋作。 夫诗岂易言哉。 自三百篇古赋之下，汉之苏、李，魏之曹、王、刘，应，去风雅未远，始有以变之。 晋初，阮、陆、潘、左之徒，尤未湮坠中逮六朝鲍、谢、颜、张出，而音韵柔慢，体格绮丽，则风雅之淳日漓矣。 暨唐初宋、杜、陈、刘，盛唐韦、柳、王、孟作，而气度音节，雄逸壮迈，度越於前者也。 而集大成者，必日少陵杜氏。 在当时，如高，李、岑、贾，亦莫之等焉。 则杜氏之於穷达圻戚，发乎声歌者，有合乎风雅而足为楷法矣。 唐末风俗侈靡，宋之称善者，苏子瞻、梅圣俞、石延年、王介甫、欧、苏、朱、杨而已。 及元，范、杨、虞、揭辈，倡遗音於绝响之余，直追盛唐，一时禁林之儒生，四方之士人，莫不宗师之。 凡江东西之问，言能诗者尤盛。 盖得乎己者，高而宇宙山川之大，近．而卉木禽虫之微，无巨细妍丑之辨，接於目者会於心，其操辞运思若江海之奔而不可遏矣。 故代之辞人墨客，以是名者，骈华竞秀，栉比鳞次，及求之大章全恢，可以跻古而式后者，复几何人哉。 然则三百篇之删取，虽出於庸人愚妇之言者，其风刺美怨，皆足以荐之廊庙，裨之政化，而王泽具存焉。 其日诗既亡而以春秋续之，则为诗者必欲继其亡者焉。 是以后之学者苟不操源迩流，发乎性静之正，资养之实，务趋於模测雕饰，窥古人之余膏剩馥，惟将和铅吮墨、剽猎纤碎，骋驾於兰曹月露之顷，以夸时自足，是岂足与言诗也哉。 余友杨君孟顼，世以诗呜，余卯岁尝读其伯父显民诗，惜不尽见。 今春延孟顼，授业余甥，采其言论风旨，恨得之晚。 且出其平素诗若干篇，获尽读之。 及扣其家，其先自伯起者，汉为名儒，世称关西夫子。 迨隋唐多显宦，有名某者，官江西某处，因迁居进贤县之水北里，实高宗麟德元年也。 至宋，有讳仲博者，举进士第，擢长沙令，转江西漕运使而终。

Heng presented several writings, titled *Zonglian Ye*, and entreated, saying: "When my late father served in Xinjian, the county academy was once the study hall of Prime Minister Zonglian of the Yuan. Hence, he named his work thus. None understood my father’s depth of learning as Master Mo did—would you honor us with a preface?" Unable to refuse, I read the texts twice and sighed in reflection: "Of scholars who pursue learning, many seek fulfillment through others, while few seek it within themselves. My friend was nurtured by the harmony of heaven and earth, the refinement of mountains and rivers, and the blessings of his ancestors. His nature was pure, his qi clear, his conduct upright and unsullied—qualities beyond the reach of mediocre scholars or vulgar men. Having fulfilled himself inwardly, he had no need of external validation. Thus, his discourse and manner arose from the simplicity of principle and the subtlety of attaining the Dao, self-evident without exhaustive inquiry, self-manifest without deliberate assertion. Was this not the fruit of his innate understanding?

Naturally, in his actions and teachings, he eschewed superficial recitation or rhetorical flourish, grounding all in the rectification of the self and sincerity of purpose. With the self rectified and sincerity established, the Way of the sages and the methods of governing the world were already complete—what need was there for superfluous elaboration? His policy proposals, lectures, and expositions all emerged from the essentials of uprightness and the methods of self-cultivation. Even the Yang and Qian of the Lu school would scarcely surpass him. His poems and verses, rooted in the truth of human nature, embodied the refined elegance of Wei and Meng, the serene simplicity of Tao and Liu.

Alas, he was never granted a grand office to fully express his harmonious and pure cultivation—how rare such men are in this sagely age! Even now, among Xinjian’s students, those who once heard his words stand firm in their resolve. Was this not the fruit of his profound influence in nurturing integrity and discipline? Yet his learning was rooted in the Lu school, and those who venerate Zhu Xi may not embrace him. Thus, his steadfast independence and unwavering clarity remain little known. Nevertheless, when one examines the essence of his thought and the substance of his words, can they truly be dismissed?

If his teachings endure, they will surely serve as wings to the words of Zhou, Cheng, Zhu, and Lu. My friend Wu Bozong has composed his epitaph, but I lack the eloquence to amplify its praise. Thus, I offer this preface in lieu of refusal, recording the origins of his work."

---

**Preface to *Yunxi’s Poetry Collection***

Mencius said: "When the traces of the true kings faded, poetry perished; with poetry gone, the *Spring and Autumn Annals* arose." How difficult it is to speak of poetry! After the *Three Hundred Poems* and the ancient *fu*, the Han poets Su and Li, and the Wei masters Cao, Wang, Liu, and Ying, still drew near to the *Airs* and *Elegances*, beginning to transform them. By the early Jin, the likes of Ruan, Lu, Pan, and Zuo had not yet let the tradition decline. Later, in the Six Dynasties, Bao, Xie, Yan, and Zhang emerged, but their tones grew delicate and languid, their forms ornate and florid—the purity of the *Airs* and *Elegances* gradually dissipated.

By the early Tang, Song, Du, Chen, and Liu arose, followed in the High Tang by Wei, Liu, Wang, and Meng, whose spirit and cadence soared with unmatched vigor. Yet the one who synthesized it all was Du of Shaoling. Even contemporaries like Gao, Li, Cen, and Jia could not rival him. In his poetry, whether in adversity or prosperity, Du’s songs aligned with the *Airs* and *Elegances*, offering a model for all. By the late Tang, customs grew extravagant, and in the Song, only Su Shi, Mei Yaochen, Shi Yannian, Wang Anshi, Ouyang Xiu, the Su brothers, Zhu Xi, and Yang Wanli were deemed exemplary. In the Yuan, Fan, Yang, Yu, and Jie revived fading echoes, directly reviving the High Tang. For a time, scholars of the imperial academy and literati from all quarters took them as masters. In the regions between Jiangdong and Jiangxi, those who excelled in poetry flourished.

Those who attained mastery within themselves found the vastness of the cosmos and mountains, the minutiae of flora and fauna—regardless of scale or beauty—stirring their hearts when perceived. Their diction and thought surged like rivers and seas, unstoppable. Thus, the literary men and ink-slingers of the age vied in splendor, arrayed like scales on a fish. Yet how many among them achieved grand and complete works, worthy of ascending to the ancients and serving as models for posterity?

The *Three Hundred Poems* were selected from the words of commoners and simple women, yet their satire, praise, and lament were fit for the ancestral temple, aiding governance and preserving the royal grace. If poetry perished and the *Spring and Autumn Annals* succeeded it, then poets must strive to revive what was lost. Yet later scholars, if they do not trace the source and follow the stream, if they do not arise from the correctness of a tranquil nature and the substance of self-cultivation, but instead chase after superficial imitation and embellishment, gleaning only the remnants of the ancients, merely dabbling in ink and plagiarizing fragments, racing to outdo one another in ephemeral verses of orchids and moonlight—how can they be deemed worthy of poetry?

My friend Yang Mengyu’s family is renowned for poetry. In my youth, I read his uncle Xianmin’s poems, though I regret not seeing them all. This spring, Mengyu was invited to tutor my nephew, and I lamented our late acquaintance as I studied his discourse and manner. He also presented several of his poems, which I read in full. Upon inquiring about his family, I learned that his ancestors, beginning with his great-uncle, were esteemed scholars, known as the "Master of Guanzhong." By the Sui and Tang, many held prominent offices. One ancestor, whose name is recorded, served in Jiangxi and later settled in Shuibei Village, Jinxian County, during the first year of Gaozong’s *Linde* reign. In the Song, a certain Zhongbo passed the imperial examinations, served as magistrate of Changsha, and was later promoted to transport commissioner of Jiangxi before his death.

chunks.original_text: 又讳龙伟者，亦举进士，为鄱阳簿，仲父季子，元为中书检校，迁礼部侍郎，终赠本部尚书。 以是族日益蕃，今凡居水北者，二十有九世矣。 其学则祖叔能，师宋监冑生见心危先生季辅，显民季子，皆学於叔能，率以家教相承。 季辅志识闲雅冲澹，晚节亦慕道家纵闭之说，延明师笃教诸子。 孟顼德充而学赡，其襟度辞韵，清丽宏达，法於杜而备众体者也。 盖世为簪缨家，其渊源之懿，研泳之习有素矣。 余固知其不以显晦荣悴累其中，而向使列之英俊之林，又安知其不可续清庙之音，以铺张盛世之述作也哉。 此亦其志夫国风、雅颂之大者焉。 抑余无似，退外乎穷山密林，旷意风月寂寥之滨，其浅陋良有以丽泽之，又岂能尽知孟顼哉。 然感夫世之知诗者，如孟顼且鲜，尸信能凌厉前古，而与造物者争衡也乎。 问属叔，於余情不获，蚓俟於异日，岂惟是哉。 许氏族谱序 尝读《周官》书，其小史之职，奠世系，辨昭穆，以定邦国之制。 虽古无谱牒，而严大宗、小宗之法，自宗法不修，而尚门地，由是而有谱牒之识焉。 斯所以昭穆不素，疏戚有别也。 然代之谱其宗者，率欲光其先，振其后，凡得同姓而显着者，必将攀授附窃而成书。 虽自欺以取夸於一时，而其尊祖明宗之法，胥失之矣，又何代夫为之后者，此学士大夫之所不取也。 盖迩而上之，莫得而详焉，是或有所诬也欤。 或不求门地之素，风俗之淳，而徒资产之厚，声利之盛，则以巨室名阀尊尚之，其於古之人久近之别，赐姓命氏之原，尚何自而考证之哉。 高阳许氏，春秋之谓齐侯、许男后也。 春秋之后无复国，其后以封为姓。 按谱，汉许氏侯者七人，王莽败，始失侯。 东汉循吏许判者，其下为汝南人，各有闻。 许靖为蜀太傅，许褚事魏封侯。 晋许孜征孝廉不起，其后称高阳为盛。 许邵爵唐安陆郡公，敬宗为龙翔相，孙日远，天宝之乱以义死。 宋祥符间，许遂为将作监、主簿。 许怡，元为江淮荆湖两浙制置使，其后族大且蕃，累仕于朝。 至某者，由某官迁抚之宜黄，因家焉，是为江右着姓。 某於谭为世戚，外兄碧渊，尝以其谱牒属序焉。 余尝感夫盛衰荣悴之理，最驳於无穷者，一何甚哉。 幼闻故家遗俗，莫盛於元，盖以享国之久，恩惠宽厚，货殖蕃硕，凡其有休声余泽者，靡不思以振复兴起者焉。 故不惟奢靡豪纵之习，而诗书之泽，孝友之风，犹彬彬间有之者矣。 迨今凡三十余年，运去物改，一日一鞠为榛莽者有矣。 其亦消长之数，信有定在也耶。 蚓以学行世、其家者，非假谱牒之存，以详其支振之远，婵嫣之自，则祖宗之嘉猷盛烈，曷有不颠飧者哉。 而能存其谱者，亦鲜矣。 其若许氏之能善宝其存，所推本者，皆穹爵令望之士，可谓敦本知自者焉。 惜乎，未识用衡，而於碧渊之言可征矣，是不辞而为之序。 赠御风子序 世之具形气者，有生於无，而无复归於有，故形载乎气，而气御乎形也。 元气运天地，而阴阳行焉。 天之覆，地之载，日月之明，四时之序，昼夜之续，鬼神之变，万物之众，其运行而不息者，皆有无自相生化者也。 古之善训人者，惟使趋乎道而已。 知趋乎道，则达有无生化之机矣。 然世之谓学者，苟声务华，饰外忘内，其於生化之有无，又岂能潜求默识也哉。

There was also one named Longwei, who likewise passed the imperial examinations and served as registrar of Poyang. His father’s younger brother and younger son both held office in the Yuan dynasty: the former as examiner in the Secretariat, later promoted to vice minister of the Ministry of Rites, and posthumously honored as minister of the same ministry. Thus the clan flourished with each generation, and those now dwelling in Shuibei number twenty-nine in descent.

Their learning originated with Shuneng, who studied under Wei Jianxiu, a student of the Song dynasty Imperial Academy, and Master Jianxin Weixian. Shuneng’s younger son Xianmin and his own younger son both received instruction from Shuneng, perpetuating the family’s scholarly tradition. Jianxin was refined in temperament and unassuming in demeanor; in his later years, he also admired Daoist teachings on seclusion and reclusion, inviting renowned masters to rigorously educate his sons. Mengyu is virtuous and erudite, his bearing and literary style marked by clarity, elegance, and breadth—modeled after Du Fu yet encompassing all poetic forms. Indeed, as a family of official rank for generations, their noble origins and long-cultivated scholarly refinement run deep.

I am certain that neither worldly success nor obscurity disturbs his inner peace. Had he been placed among the ranks of the eminent, who is to say he could not have continued the sacred music of the ancestral temple, enriching the literary legacy of a flourishing age? Such is his aspiration toward the grand tradition of *Guofeng*, *Ya*, and *Song*. As for myself, unworthy as I am, exiled to remote mountains and dense forests, my mind wanders the desolate shores of wind and moonlight. My own shallowness has surely been refined by his brilliance, yet how could I fully comprehend Mengyu?

Yet I am struck by the rarity of those in this world who truly understand poetry—even Mengyu is seldom recognized. How few can soar beyond the ancients and contend with the Creator! When I asked about his uncle, my affection for him left me no choice but to await another day to do justice to his merits. Is this not so?

---

**Preface to the Xu Clan Genealogy**

I have read the *Rites of Zhou*, which states that the duty of the *xiaoshi* (minor historian) is to establish lineage, distinguish senior and junior branches, and thereby determine the order of the state. Though ancient times lacked genealogical records, the strict distinction between major and minor clans was maintained. Only after the decline of the clan system did emphasis shift to family status, giving rise to genealogical records. These serve to clarify lineage and distinguish degrees of kinship.

Yet those who compile genealogies often seek to glorify their ancestors and elevate their descendants. Whenever they encounter a prominent figure of the same surname, they invariably claim affiliation, fabricating connections to complete their records. Though such self-deception may bring temporary pride, it undermines the principles of honoring ancestors and clarifying lineage. How, then, can later generations trace their roots? This is why scholars and officials reject such practices.

Tracing further back, details grow scarce, and inaccuracies may arise. Some disregard a family’s historical standing or the purity of its customs, valuing only wealth and fame. They revere great households and prestigious lineages, yet how can they verify distinctions of antiquity, the origins of surnames, or the bestowal of clan names?

The Gaoyang Xu clan descends from the Marquis of Xu and the Lord of Qi in the *Spring and Autumn Annals*. After the *Spring and Autumn* period, the state ceased to exist, and its descendants took the former fief as their surname. According to the genealogy, seven members of the Xu clan held marquisates in the Han dynasty, losing their titles only after Wang Mang’s downfall. In the Eastern Han, the upright official Xu Pan’s descendants settled in Runan, each branch gaining renown. Xu Jing served as Grand Tutor of Shu, while Xu Chu, in service to Wei, was enfeoffed as a marquis. In the Jin dynasty, Xu Zi was nominated as *xiaolian* but declined office; his descendants flourished in Gaoyang. Xu Shao was enfeoffed as Duke of Anlu in the Tang, and his grandson Jingzong became prime minister of Longxiang. Xu Riyuan died for righteousness during the *Tianbao* rebellion. In the Song *Xiangfu* era, Xu Sui served as director of the Directorate for Palace Buildings. Xu Yi, in the Yuan dynasty, was appointed pacification commissioner of Jianghuai, Jinghu, and the Two Zhe provinces. His descendants grew numerous and held successive court positions. One ancestor, through official promotion, was transferred to Yihuang in Fuzhou, where the family settled, becoming a prominent clan of Jiangyou.

My connection to the Xu family is one of kinship by marriage. My cousin Biyuan once entrusted me with their genealogy to compose a preface. I have long reflected on the inexorable cycles of prosperity and decline, glory and hardship—how profoundly they unfold without end! In my youth, I heard of the customs of old families, none more illustrious than those of the Yuan dynasty. Due to its long reign, its benevolence and generosity, and the flourishing of commerce, all who bore its legacy sought to revive and restore it. Thus, not only did extravagance and indulgence prevail, but the influence of poetry and books, along with the virtues of filial piety and brotherly love, still occasionally thrived.

Yet over thirty years have passed, and with the shift of fortune, all has changed. What once stood proud now lies in ruins. Is this not the inevitable ebb and flow of destiny? For those who uphold their family’s legacy through learning and conduct, without genealogical records to trace their lineage’s reach or the origins of their branches, how can the noble deeds and illustrious achievements of their ancestors avoid fading into obscurity? Few indeed are those who preserve their genealogies. That the Xu clan has so carefully safeguarded theirs, tracing their roots to officials of high rank and esteemed reputation, may be called a return to fundamentals and self-awareness.

Alas, I have yet to meet the standard, but Biyuan’s words compel me. Thus, I offer this preface without hesitation.

---

**Preface to *Zeng Yu Fengzi***

All beings endowed with form and *qi* arise from non-being and ultimately return to it. Thus, form is borne by *qi*, and *qi* governs form. The primordial *qi* animates heaven and earth, while yin and yang operate within it. Heaven’s canopy, earth’s support, the radiance of the sun and moon, the sequence of the four seasons, the alternation of day and night, the transformations of ghosts and spirits, the multitude of the ten thousand things—all their ceaseless movements arise from the mutual generation and transformation of being and non-being.

The ancients who excelled in instructing others guided them solely toward the Dao. To understand the Dao is to grasp the mechanism of being and non-being, generation and transformation. Yet today’s so-called scholars pursue empty fame and superficial adornment, neglecting the inner for the outer. How can they silently seek and inwardly comprehend the interplay of being and non-being, generation and transformation?

chunks.original_text: 余居耆山中，闲游鹤松下，值一道者，蓬万偷然，揖而言日：吾游江海问久矣，尝扣异人以金液还丹之道，信夫列御寇指尸轮神马之说，而有御风之神化者也。 吾虽未知能也，其然乎，其不然乎，愿有以发之。 日：风之为物也，声而不形，蒙庄氏谓之大块噫黑是焉。 其御也果有冯乎。 所冯虚者，则何致福之数数然也。 所冯者非虚，又何福之可致耶，况数数也哉。 是故难免乎，犹有所待者也。 孰若无所御而行，是无待於外矣。 故乘天地之正，而御六气之辨，以游无穷者，彼且恶乎待哉。 彼列御寇之御乎尸轮神马者，乃一气之往来无穷，是托乎御风也，果何待哉。 故其游之不息，非以边涯可得而测焉，况旬有五日而后返耶。 有息而后返，返而未尝不息矣。 特有之所以乘无，无之所以御有也。 及乎非有非无，而生生化化之机尽矣。 子之於学也，必求夫天地之正，六气之辨，修之於己，日积月至而后形神黑化。 亦御乎尸轮神马之无穷，则风不待御而行矣。 其视致福，乃吾无所用者哉。 舍是而欲之，虽使飞廉列缺，侍乎飕车霆辙，驾乎云道星衢，尚何能御哉。 虽然，凡造乎道者，必去浮幻，绝识染，形如槁木，心若死灰，视世之贵者为埃壤，身之重者若土宜，则其自待也轻，举天下无毫发之足累其中。 犹冯虚而行，不假於御而莫知止也。 虽天地之外，不可以迹限之也。 蚓子以刚劲之质，参究之学，使洞视有无之表，而游乎逍遥之墟，广漠之野，若万窍之怒号，众窍之为虚，参参乎之不闻，刁刁乎之不见，又何众窍之谓地籁，比竹之谓人籁，吹万之谓天籁也乎。 惟听於无声，视於无形，则有无之问，皆一吹万也。 斯求造物者之所冯哉。 而吾独不得而至焉，子其勉之。 道者因请以自号，并录其言而别。 送琴士朱宗明序 乐之所以致和也，极乎天而蟠乎地，行乎阴阳而通乎鬼神。 是故大乐与天地同和、其感於物而动，乃形於声，声成文谓之音，音之发有喜怒衰乐、欣戚邪正存焉。 此君子之於琴瑟，斯须不可去也。 故曰琴，乐之统也，君子所当御也。 盖凡接於耳目，具於四体，必礼以节之，而琴足以闲邪涤非，怡心养性，是得乎性情之正焉。 其与夫鸾和佩玉，雅颂之音，无故不彻也一宜矣。 其由羲、农、虞、舜、文王、孔子而下，伯牙、屈宋之作也，或感於忧思，形於悲叹，放於悦择。 始於斋汶杳施，划然若怒； 终而飒爽激烈，凄然若悲。 其急也，风雨震而崖石裂焉； 其缓也，波涛作而蛟龙兴焉。 其大也，麒骥骤而干戚举焉； 其微也，泉溜滴而蚤浆语焉。 此其千态万状，不可得而尽也。 信能与阴阳相摩，天地相荡也矣。 在夫得之心而应之手也，非习之有素，不亦难乎。 且必得乎性情之正，而后不失乎圣贤之余韵也。 岂徒悦乎流俗之观听也欤。 昔之称师襄、师旷、师文者，其去远矣。 其下损益者，雍门周、司马相如、蔡当、孙登、嵇康、桓谭、杨收之徒，一各擅其说。 近代之以是名者，惟晓山徐氏子方、袁氏敏仲、毛氏伯振。 杨氏学於徐、袁，而呜一时者，起敬玲氏，是有江制二操之辨，后皆徐袁为宗焉。 余少嗜其学，闻於通都大邑，遇呜於是者，必叩焉。 其日制学者皆然，而徒夸多竞靡而已。 求其音节雄逸，兴度幽远者，亦甚鲜矣。
chunks.translated_text:
While dwelling in the mountains of Qi, I wandered leisurely beneath the pines where cranes roosted. There I encountered a Daoist, his hair wild and unkempt, who bowed and spoke: "I have roamed rivers and seas for many years, once questioning extraordinary persons about the Way of the Golden Elixir and Returning Cinnabar. I believe in Liezi’s teachings on the Corpse-Chariot and Spirit-Steed, and that there are those who attain divine transformation through riding the wind. Though I do not yet know if I am capable, is it so—or is it not? I wish to have this clarified."

I replied: "Wind, as a thing, has sound but no form. Master Zhuang called it the great sigh of the cosmos. Does riding it truly rely on something? If what it relies upon is emptiness, how can one repeatedly attain fortune? If what it relies upon is not emptiness, how can fortune be attained at all—let alone repeatedly? Thus, it is difficult to escape dependence. How much better to move without relying on anything, to be without dependence on externals. Therefore, those who ride the correctness of heaven and earth and harness the transformations of the six qi to wander the boundless—what do they await? Liezi’s riding of the Corpse-Chariot and Spirit-Steed is but the endless coming and going of a single qi, a reliance on riding the wind—yet what does it truly await? Thus, their wandering knows no rest, and its limits cannot be measured, let alone returning after fifteen days. To rest is to return, and to return is never without rest. This is how being rides upon non-being, and non-being governs being. When it reaches the state of neither being nor non-being, the mechanism of ceaseless generation and transformation is fully realized.

In your studies, you must seek the correctness of heaven and earth and the transformations of the six qi, cultivating them within yourself until, over months and years, form and spirit undergo dark transformation. Then, riding the boundless Corpse-Chariot and Spirit-Steed, the wind moves without needing to be ridden. As for attaining fortune—it becomes something I have no use for. To abandon this and pursue other paths, even if one commands the winds of Feilian and the lightning of Lieque, rides the thunderous chariot of the storm, or traverses the starry roads of the clouds, how can one truly ride anything?

Yet all who approach the Dao must cast aside illusion, sever perceptual defilements, make their form like withered wood and their heart like dead ashes. They must regard the world’s treasures as dust and their own weighty bodies as clods of earth. Then, their self-reliance becomes light, and not even the entire world can burden their minds with so much as a hair’s weight. They move as if relying on emptiness, needing no vehicle yet knowing no bounds. Even beyond heaven and earth, their traces cannot be confined.

You, with your resolute nature and rigorous inquiry, must penetrate beyond being and non-being to wander the carefree wastes and boundless wilds. Like the roaring of ten thousand hollows, the emptiness of all openings—where nothing is heard, nothing is seen—what then are the earthly pipes of the hollows, the human pipes of bamboo flutes, or the heavenly pipes of the myriad winds? Only by listening to the soundless and seeing the formless can one realize that between being and non-being, all is but the myriad winds of a single breath. This is what those who seek the Creator rely upon. Yet I alone have not attained it—strive onward."

The Daoist then asked to adopt this as his name and recorded these words before parting.

**Preface to the Zither Master Zhu Zongming**

Music’s power to bring harmony extends to the heavens and coils through the earth, moving through yin and yang and penetrating ghosts and spirits. Thus, grand music harmonizes with heaven and earth. Its resonance with things manifests in sound, and sound shaped into patterns is called tone. In tones arise joy and anger, sorrow and delight, exultation and grief, perversity and uprightness. This is why the noble person never parts with the zither and se for even a moment. As it is said: the zither is the essence of music, what the noble person ought to master.

All that enters the ears and eyes, all that fills the four limbs, must be regulated by ritual, and the zither suffices to dispel perversity, cleanse error, gladden the heart, and nurture the nature—thus attaining the correctness of human feelings. It is no different from the harmonious chimes of jade pendants or the refined sounds of the *Ya* and *Song* odes, which should not be silenced without cause.

From the times of Fuxi, Shennong, Yu, Shun, King Wen, and Confucius down to the works of Boya, Qu Yuan, and Song Yu, some compositions arose from sorrowful thoughts, taking shape in mournful sighs or expressions of joy and choice. They begin with faint and distant notes, suddenly surging like anger; they end with a swift, stirring intensity, mournful as grief. In their urgency, they shake the wind and rain, splitting cliffs; in their slowness, they stir waves, rousing dragons. In their grandeur, they spur the gallop of unicorns and the brandishing of shields and axes; in their subtlety, they mimic the drip of springs and the whispers of insects. Their thousand forms and ten thousand postures cannot be fully described. Truly, they can rub against yin and yang and resonate with heaven and earth.

Yet to grasp this in the heart and express it through the hands requires long practice—how could it be otherwise? Only by attaining the correctness of human feelings can one preserve the lingering echoes of the sages and worthies. How could it be merely to please the vulgar ears and eyes of the masses?

The masters of old—Shi Xiang, Shi Kuang, and Shi Wen—are long gone. Those who came after, modifying their teachings—Yongmen Zhou, Sima Xiangru, Cai Dang, Sun Deng, Ji Kang, Huan Tan, and Yang Shou—each excelled in their own way. Among those renowned in recent times for this art are Xu Zifang of Xiaoshan, Yuan Minzhong, and Mao Bozhen. Yang, who studied under Xu and Yuan, rose to prominence in his time as Qi Ling. His *Two Compositions of Jiang* became models, and later generations took Xu and Yuan as their standard.

From my youth, I have been devoted to this study. In great cities, whenever I encountered someone skilled in it, I would inquire. Yet most who claim mastery today merely boast of their abundance and compete in extravagance. Those whose tones are bold and transcendent, whose spirit soars to distant realms, are exceedingly rare."

chunks.original_text: 闽士朱宗明氏，师於袁玲其友也。 今春来游吾山，相与扫石鼓于岘泉之上，其曲也、调也，皆清深雅淡，雄逸飘纵，信非夸多竞美者比也。 采其论说，必以得性情之正为要。 少游四方，多所资访，我朝国初，首以荐赴京，力辞获还。 凡闽之巨室大姓，更相延致之。 而其齿发向暮，乃得乎音之妙者，宜非一日也。 然昔人谓之高山流水者，获与之陶情写意於风林月碉中矣。 其别去也，岂不梦寐乎吾天籁云涛之听也乎。 而亦果何为黄锺白雪之音也。 特恐均不能忘乎耳哉。 於其行遂抱琴鼓之溪之辩，再鼓而不知其有离声也。 乃序其盘以为赠。 游仙岩诗序 予尝观夫世人，静躁劳逸之异也，其出处语默，必见乎性情之趁好焉，是岂得强而至哉。 苟强而至，又岂造夫趣之真也。 夫吾山仙岩，凡居二十有四，闻於四方久矣。 由汉天师炼丹兹山，而龙虎现岩，因益名。 由是天下士人，无贵贱老壮，凡偶经特谒者，靡不愿一游焉。 以是游帆曳棹而往者，岁无虚月矣。
chunks.translated_text:
The Fujian scholar Zhu Zongming studied under Yuan Ling, a friend of mine. This spring, he came to travel through our mountains, and together we swept the stone drums by Xian Spring. His melodies and tunes were all pure, profound, elegant, and refined—bold and transcendent, soaring and unrestrained—truly beyond comparison with those who merely boast of their abundance and compete in extravagance. In his discussions, he invariably took the attainment of the true nature of feeling as essential. In his youth, he traveled widely, drawing from many sources. At the beginning of our dynasty, he was first recommended to the capital but firmly declined and returned. All the great families and prominent clans of Fujian vied to invite him. Yet only now, in his advanced years, has he attained the subtleties of sound—surely not the work of a single day.

As the ancients said of "lofty mountains and flowing waters," he found in him one with whom to cultivate the spirit and express the heart amid wind-swept forests and moonlit cliffs. When he departed, how could I not dream of the celestial sounds and surging waves of his music? And what indeed were those tones of *Huangzhong* and *Baixue*? I feared only that my ears could never forget them. As he left, I took up my zither and played *The Debate by the Stream*, strumming twice without ever sensing the sound of parting.

Thus, I write this preface as a gift for his journey.

**Preface to "Roaming the Immortal Crags"**

I have often observed how people differ in their stillness and restlessness, their toil and ease. Their conduct and speech, their silence and expression, inevitably reveal the inclinations of their nature—how could these be forced? If forced, how could they ever reach the truth of such inclinations?

Our mountain’s Immortal Crags, numbering twenty-four in all, have long been renowned throughout the land. Since the Han-era Celestial Master refined his elixir here, dragons and tigers have appeared in the rocks, lending the place its name. From then on, scholars near and far—regardless of rank, age, or strength—who passed by or made a special pilgrimage never failed to wish for a visit. Thus, boats and oars have come and gone without cease, month after month, year after year.

chunks.original_text: 洪武丙子季秋六日，予偕馆宾杨公孟顼、仲氏湛碧、昊甥汝绪、侍游者王景山、昊处渊、袁止安也，命舟溪涤，崇酒磕般而发焉，纵波冲渚而下，不瑜时而达。 是夕息岩之左，日演法观，乃汉天师祠也。 危台杰阁，高出天际，水帘斗坛，丹鳌芝岩，交列左右，相与偃息。 瑜夕，明旦发舟，篙人指顾，下上应接，娣陌之不暇。 而冱岛洲渚之问，怪石异木，幽葩奇卉，秾褥重馥，皆联芳独秀之可喜也。 顷而旋汀历淑，若助洼抵岸之触，侧窦隐隙之险，惟乌柄揉攀，而人迹莫能即焉。 或依乎深林隘谷者，渔舍隐焉。 或蔽乎荒榛野渚者，樵径纡焉。 是殆武陵桃源不异也。 已而开蹲啜茗，迩流而下，颠崖绝壁突怒而起者，蛟腾豹跃，龙襄虎踞，俯首而伏者，屏列障辟，云奔雾涌，千态万状，层见迭出，而穴其嵚空坛毗者，庖庾昙牖，机杼梁堵，毕具其问，使人仰视慕羡，心融神释，信不知其有人问世矣。 下视澄潭一碧，灵籁四起，而其干霄丽日，排空而上者，岌素崴蘗、惟岩峙谷耸，苍峪绮错而已。 远而狂澜浅渚，肃汶泞衬，余不知其有穷也。 久之即岩下，枢衣而上，悬石万仞，若垂盖覆宇，可坐数十许人。 遂陈觞罗俎，而饮於是。 吟者歌焉，琴者弦焉，绘者图焉，尽一日之惧，移夕乃已。 时天风西来，恍若欲蹑空驾浮，而兴不可遏。 遂命舟访岩之右，日明诚观者，昊大宗师河图仙坛也。 天且暮，乃明火趋宿。 主柯者日昊从善氏，善日者术，延谈竟夕，明日乃还。 所赋诗若干，不觉盈袖成卷矣。 孟顼乃次第成恢，而告日：人生行乐耳。 今夫名山大川，为仙真之窟宅，吾闻有年矣。 不啻蓬莱、闱风、方壶、圆娇之胜也。 世之愿一游而不可得者多矣。 或闻而以为怪诞之夸，而未之信焉，今也幸遂一览。 若安期、羡门，飞仙狡脍之适，尽在目睫问矣，岂不自幸也欤。 愿序诸作之首，以纪一时之胜集，而遗之无穷也。 余不辞而叹日：夫开辟以来，天地位而山川育焉。 兹岩也，屹立旷劫，曷有倾圯，前乎千万载，莫知其阅废兴消长之几何也，其能同此乐者几何人矣？ 后乎千万载，孰知夫能同今日之乐者几何人哉？ 然则羁华轩冕，没溺氛垢，或风雨之晦冥，人事之欣戚，不可胜纪。 而不能从兹游者，其相去岂不霄壤之问哉。 蚓是游也，且有词章弦咏之乐，视昔之赤壁、刻溪之兴，亦未必多让也，其能已於言乎。 抑世之躁者思静，劳者慕逸，其有得夫天趣之真否乎。 遂乐其请而序之。 还真集序 仙道自古尚矣，由黄帝问道广成子，世称黄老，盖广成即老子也。 仙之说始焉，若唐之钱铿，夏之啸父，商之宛丘、周氏王乔，三代则固有之。 而周穆建草楼以延士，其说始着。 殆秦皇、汉武，惑方士药石之术，虽王次仲、东方朔之徒而不知师，而其邪说滋蔓淆杂，卒以顶身，则世之鸿生．硕士，并起而訾斥之，亦宜矣。 若汉魏伯阳，仿《易》撰《参同契》，本《古文龙虎经》而充越之。 以是丹道倡明，不溺於金石、草木、云霞、补导之术，一明乎身心神黑自然之理，假卦爻晷刻以则之，靡不合乎奇耦象数也。 厥后由锺离云房授唐吕岩，则祖述其说，而歌辞论辨，庶得乎指归之正，代亦不乏其人焉。 若宋之张紫阳、石杏林、陈泥丸、白紫清、李玉溪、李清庵，皆一时杰出，凡其辞旨亦不下伯阳，而互有深造默会者焉。
chunks.translated_text:
On the sixth day of the ninth lunar month in the *bingzi* year of the Hongwu reign, I set forth with my academy guests—Master Yang Mengxu, my second brother Zhan Bi, my nephew Wu Ruxu—and our attendants Wang Jingshan, Wu Chuyuan, and Yuan Zhi’an. We ordered a boat to be readied at the creek’s cleansing waters, loaded wine and provisions, then cast off, riding the waves past islets until we arrived in no time at all.

That evening, we rested to the left of the Crags at the *Yanfa Abbey*, the shrine of the Han-era Celestial Master. Towering terraces and soaring pavilions pierced the heavens, while water curtains draped the altar platforms, cinnabar turtles and mushroom crags arrayed to either side—all offered respite for our repose. The next dawn, we embarked again, the boatmen’s poles and gestures guiding us up and down in ceaseless succession, leaving no leisure to admire the winding paths. Yet among the isles and shores, strange rocks and rare trees, secluded blossoms and exotic blooms flourished in lush, fragrant profusion, each vying in solitary splendor.

Soon we turned toward the shallows, skirting coves where the boat’s hull scraped hidden hollows and jagged crevices—places where only birds could perch or cling, and no human trace could reach. Some coves nestled deep in forests and narrow valleys, sheltering fishermen’s huts; others lay concealed by wild thickets and overgrown islets, where woodcutters’ trails wound in meandering seclusion. This was scarcely different from the Peach Blossom Spring of Wuling. Presently, we paused to brew tea by the stream, drifting downstream as sheer cliffs and precipitous crags reared up in sudden fury—some like leaping dragons and bounding leopards, others like crouching tigers and coiled serpents. Those that bowed low formed natural screens and barriers, while clouds surged and mists billowed in endless transformations. Where hollows gaped in the towering rocks, kitchens, granaries, windows, and weaving looms seemed fully furnished within, inspiring awe and longing as one gazed upward. The mind dissolved, the spirit released, one truly forgot the mortal world existed.

Below, the limpid pool shimmered in emerald clarity, while ethereal harmonies arose on all sides. Yet above, soaring into the azure skies and brilliant sunlight, only jagged peaks and towering ridges stood—verdant ravines and intricate ridges woven together. In the distance, wild waves and shallow shoals, solemn streams and muddy shallows stretched on without end. After a long while, we disembarked at the base of the Crags, securing our robes to ascend. Suspended boulders hung like canopies over the void, spacious enough to seat dozens. There we laid out wine cups and dishes, drinking our fill. Some recited poetry, others plucked the zither, still others sketched the scene—thus we passed the day in delight, lingering until evening.

Just then, a western wind arose, as if urging us to tread the void and ride the floating clouds, our spirits irrepressible. We ordered the boat to seek the Crags’ right flank, where the *Mingcheng Abbey*—the *Hetu* Immortal Altar of Grand Master Wu—stood. Night had fallen by the time we lit torches to hasten to our lodging. Our host, a descendant of the Wu clan named Congshan, was well-versed in divination and astrology. We conversed through the night, departing the next morning. The poems we composed filled our sleeves, forming a scroll before we knew it.

Mengxu then arranged them in order and declared: “Life is for joy alone. These famed mountains and rivers are the dwelling places of immortals and perfected beings—I have heard of them for years. They are no less wondrous than Penglai, Weifeng, Fanghu, or Yuanjiao. Many long to visit but never can. Some hear of them and dismiss the tales as fantastical exaggerations, refusing to believe. Yet today, by good fortune, we have beheld them with our own eyes. The realms of Anqi and Xianmen, the flights of immortals and feasts of leviathans, all lie within a blink’s reach—how could we not count ourselves fortunate? I beg you to preface these works, to record this gathering’s splendor and leave it for posterity.”

I could not refuse and sighed in assent: “Since the dawn of creation, heaven and earth have stood in their places, and mountains and rivers have flourished. These Crags have towered through endless eons, never crumbling. For thousands upon thousands of years before us, who can say how many cycles of rise and fall, growth and decay they have witnessed? How many have shared in this joy? For thousands upon thousands of years to come, who can say how many will know this same delight? Yet those entangled in worldly glory, drowned in mundane filth, buffeted by stormy gloom or the vicissitudes of human affairs—how vast is the gulf between them and those who wander here! This journey, with its pleasures of poetry, music, and song, need not yield to the famed excursions of Red Cliff or the Ke River. How could I remain silent?”

Moreover, the restless yearn for stillness, the weary long for ease—yet how many truly grasp the essence of nature’s truth? Thus, I gladly acceded to his request and composed this preface.

---

**Preface to the *Huanzhen Collection***

The Dao of immortality has been revered since antiquity. When the Yellow Emperor sought the Way from Guangchengzi, the school of Huang-Lao arose, for Guangcheng was none other than Laozi. Thus began the teachings of immortality. In the Tang, there was Qian Keng; in the Xia, Xiaofu; in the Shang, Wuanqiu; and in the Zhou, Wang Qiao of the Zhou clan—such figures existed even in the Three Dynasties. Yet it was King Mu of Zhou who built a thatched pavilion to receive scholars, bringing their doctrines into prominence.

Later, the First Emperor of Qin and Emperor Wu of Han were deluded by the arts of alchemists and elixirs. Even Wang Cizhong and Dongfang Shuo, though of their time, failed to find true masters. Their heterodox teachings spread and intermingled, ultimately leading to their downfall. Thus, the great scholars and eminent minds of the age rose together to condemn them—rightly so.

Yet in the Han, Wei Boyang modeled his *Cantong Qi* after the *Book of Changes*, expanding upon the *Ancient Text of the Dragon and Tiger Classic*. Through this, the Dao of the Elixir was illuminated, free from the pitfalls of metallurgy, herbalism, cloud-gazing, or breathwork. It clarified the natural principles of body, mind, spirit, and vitality, using the trigrams, lines, and timekeeping to establish its rules—all harmonizing with the patterns of odd and even, images and numbers.

Later, Zhongli Quan transmitted his teachings to Lü Yan of the Tang, who upheld and expounded them in songs, discourses, and debates, nearing the true essence of the tradition. Such figures have never been lacking through the ages. In the Song, Zhang Ziyang, Shi Xinglin, Chen Niuwan, Bai Ziqing, Li Yuxi, and Li Qing’an—all were outstanding masters of their time. Their words and ideas were no less profound than Boyang’s, each achieving deep, silent understanding in their own way.

The span of a thousand or ten thousand years—how is it that their words align as if tallying broken seals? This is no coincidence, but the natural outcome. For the principles of a thousand or ten thousand generations remain the same, as do the hearts of men. What causes divergence is invariably the perverse and deceptive doctrines, either contrived to impress the present age or to delude later generations—how could these ever truly accord with the natural Dao of body, mind, spirit, and qi?

Thus, the ancients invariably transmitted their teachings only to the worthy, for the Dao does not spread in vain. Moreover, if a master does not guard the profound and abstruse mysteries, refusing to reveal them indiscriminately, while the learner lacks the solid foundation of accumulated merit and cultivated conduct—merely adorning themselves with empty formalities and pretense, no different from those who chase fame and self-aggrandizement—how could they ever speak of the Dao? How could they give voice to its truths?

The Master of Hunran of Linjiang in Nanchang, once of another surname, was broadly learned. Having encountered an extraordinary person and received secret transmissions, he remained diligent in discourse and writing. I have long read his words, and though we met briefly at an inn, haste prevented a thorough inquiry. This spring, my disciple Yuan Wenyi returned from Wu, bringing his work *The Collection of Returning to the True*, and asked me to inscribe a preface. After savoring it twice, I find it truly conveys the essence of the Golden Elixir and the returning cinnabar, elucidating both the subtle and the manifest, the principle and its application. If one cultivates accordingly, even those who ascend to meet Ziyang or Qing’an may find themselves neither ahead nor behind.

I have long lamented the enduring corruption of superficial, reckless, and heterodox habits in the world, which seem impossible to eradicate entirely. Yet I rejoice that these words may serve to rouse and rectify the ills of this declining age. If steadfast scholars and upright individuals possess the discernment to distinguish fine jade from common stone, then wandering in the primordial radiance of the undifferentiated chaos, refining qi beyond the merging of primordial mists, will be no difficult feat. This is how one fully grasps the return to the origin and the consummation of the end, exhausting the divine and comprehending transformation.

Perhaps one day, I may summon the yellow crane to descend from the skies, and together we shall discuss these matters by the rivers and isles of the Xiang—there is still time. This preface stands at the beginning of the compilation.

chunks.original_text: 耆山无为天师张宇初撰 说传书 太素说 子列子之言日：有太易，有太初，有太始，有太素。 太易未见气，太初气之始，太始形之始，太素质之始，气形质具而未相离，故曰浑沦。 浑沦者，万物相浑沦而未相离也。 夫气，形质之始，阴阳未分而体浑沦，分则窍凿而混沌死，浑沦者离矣。 然三者常包括终始环互柄伏，外若离而须臾不违於消息问者，去浑沦未尝远也。 盖气行乎天地者，为风雨霜露，山川溪谷； 具乎人与物，为四体百骸。 虽飞潜动植，一本万殊，皆囿於形质者也。 未见气之始，固莫得而测，其备於质者，可得而穷焉。 天之苍苍，太虚澄彻，其正色也。 而晦冥变化起於倏忽，苍苍之色遂翳然，非晦冥变化，不能尽其在天者矣。 人禀气质之正，其情炽欲滥，则刚柔#1善恶着，是漓其淳，杂其粹，涅其洁，若质之素则最最乎混矣。 然非刚柔善恶，亦不能尽其在人者矣。 物皆然，动静往复，均不啬焉。 故物之质者，非文饰不华。 味之真者，非盐蘗不调。 音之澹者，非律吕不和。 此物性之必然也。 人之所以必惩欲复初，而后淳者不漓，粹者不杂，洁者不涅，其清明之体昭昭焉具矣。 是足以见吾刚柔善恶，犹天之晦冥倏忽，其本质之素未始有动静者焉。 虽然，世或持其说以自修，特养素而未能游乎太素，非游乎太素，其能见质之始乎。 抑质者常，华者弊，质者汨人，华者悦人。 志夫道者，必去华以返质。 能返乎质，则虑精神明，表裹贞白，万物浑沦，而不离。 是非见其始哉。 君州武当山五龙宫高士练太素，学博而行端，居吾山二十余年，持践克笃，常静处一室，不与世接。 昔先君常礼之，及予袭教，凡吾道家言多所资究焉。 是岂不能游乎太素，而独若然哉。 今秋欲还，余固留不可，因谓曰：古今名山川，必仙真所居，皆所柄息，亦何限乎是归也。 然予闻是山奇秀冠天下，岂无若安期、羡门者，潜逸其问。 太素其将征会焉，以廓其浑沦，而返乎瞑津之初，外乎形气之囿，尚何求乎质之始欤。 於其行并合其说，练喜请书以识别。 纯一子说 吁江张彦宏氏，家世着德望。 余去春谒西山、华盖，道吁而还，始识之。 爱其姿纯笃，因语焉，知求吾道言尤切，尝以纯一子自号。 值还，未暇论也。 今春来游吾山，余同弟彦玑与之游龙井、观尘湖、琵琶、云台、藐姑诸峰之秀，濯狂澜，坐盘石，若与天游，莫知其人问世也。 彦宏因请曰：尝告以纯一子之号，今获侍兹游，敢请发其义。 余指水而与之言曰：水，静物也，深源穷壑，泓澄一掬。 及发其窟怒，腾跃百折，下走不知其几千百里，大而江海，小而溪谷，触石则怒，激风则呜。 虽遇棘而塞，遭秽而浊，鱼龙宅其深，林木翳其幽，风雨晦其润，无能御滞之。 昼夜不息，须臾莫可遏者，其势之所遇然也。 於其体之挣明，非棘能塞，非秽能浊，无不容而无不烛者，元气行之。 道之所谓法者，本诸气。 水行天地问，犹气行乎身。 动静往来，一呼吸之顷，盈虚消息具焉。 人心制乎气，本净且明，，其虚灵昭昭，若泓澄焉。 惟其徇欲而蔽，感物而动，稍不加持治之功，其役於外者，颠仆交错，犹水之窟怒腾跃，势不可御。 其气散而为思虑情欲，若塞而浊者宜矣。

Master Qishan, the Celestial Master of Non-Action, Zhang Yuchu, presents:

**On the *Tai Su* and the Sayings of Liezi**

Liezi spoke of the sequence: There is *Tai Yi* (Supreme Change), *Tai Chu* (Supreme Beginning), *Tai Shi* (Supreme Commencement), and *Tai Su* (Supreme Simplicity).

*Tai Yi* is the state before qi emerges. *Tai Chu* is the beginning of qi. *Tai Shi* is the beginning of form. *Tai Su* is the beginning of substance. When qi, form, and substance are complete yet undivided, this is called *hunlun* (primordial chaos). *Hunlun* describes the state where the myriad things are intermingled and inseparable.

Qi is the origin of form and substance. Before yin and yang separate, its body is *hunlun*. Once divided, it is carved and chiseled, and the *hundun* (chaos) dies—*hunlun* is lost. Yet these three—qi, form, and substance—constantly encompass beginning and end, cycling and interweaving. Outwardly, they appear separate, but in the fleeting interplay of growth and decay, they never depart from *hunlun*. For qi courses through heaven and earth as wind, rain, frost, and dew, as mountains, rivers, and valleys. Within humans and all things, it manifests as the four limbs and the hundred bones. Though creatures fly or burrow, move or grow, each unique in its myriad forms, all are confined by form and substance.

The beginning of qi, unseen, remains unfathomable. Yet its fullness in substance can be exhaustively explored. The azure of the sky is the true color of the Great Void, pristine and clear. But when darkness and transformation arise in an instant, the azure hue becomes obscured. Without these shifts of darkness and change, the fullness of heaven’s nature cannot be realized.

Humans receive the purity of qi and substance. When passions flare and desires overflow, hardness and softness, good and evil become manifest—this dilutes their purity, mixes their essence, and stains their clarity. Yet if substance were utterly undifferentiated, how could the fullness of human nature be expressed? All things follow this principle. In motion and stillness, advance and retreat, none withhold their nature.

Thus, the substance of things, without adornment, lacks splendor. The true flavor of taste, without salt or bitterness, lacks harmony. The subtlety of sound, without pitch and rhythm, lacks concord. This is the inevitable nature of things. Humans must curb desire to return to their origin, so that purity is not diluted, essence not mixed, and clarity not stained. Then the luminous body of pure brightness becomes fully evident. Here we see that our hardness and softness, good and evil, are like heaven’s fleeting darkness and change—yet the original purity of our substance remains unmoved in stillness or motion.

Nevertheless, those in the world who uphold this teaching for self-cultivation may nurture purity but fail to wander in *Tai Su*. Without wandering in *Tai Su*, how can they perceive the origin of substance? Substance endures, while adornment decays. Substance nourishes, while adornment pleases. Those who aspire to the Dao must shed adornment to return to substance. By returning to substance, the mind becomes clear, the spirit bright, and inner and outer align in integrity. The myriad things merge in *hunlun* yet remain undivided—is this not perceiving their origin?

The scholar Lian Taisu of Wudang Mountain’s Five Dragons Palace has studied broadly and conducted himself with rectitude. He has dwelled on our mountain for over twenty years, steadfast in practice, residing in quietude within a single chamber, untouched by the world. My late father once honored him, and since I inherited this teaching, I have drawn much from his inquiries into our Daoist traditions. Could he not wander in *Tai Su* and yet remain thus? This autumn, he wished to return home, and though I urged him to stay, he declined. I said to him: "From ancient times, famous mountains and rivers have been the abodes of immortals and perfected beings. Why limit yourself to returning here? Yet I have heard this mountain’s wonders surpass all under heaven. Are there not recluses like Anqi or Xianmen hidden within its peaks? Taisu, you should seek their company to expand your *hunlun* and return to the primordial state before the merging of mists, transcending the confines of form and qi. What more would you seek of the origin of substance?"

As he prepared to depart, I combined these teachings for him. Lian gladly requested that I record them as a keepsake.

**The Pure One’s Discourse**

Ah Jiang’s Zhang Yanhong comes from a family of renowned virtue. Last spring, I visited Xishan and Hua Gai, passing through Ah Jiang on my return, where I first met him. I admired his sincere and earnest demeanor, and in conversation, learned of his fervent pursuit of our Daoist teachings. He has styled himself "The Pure One." Upon his departure, I had no time to discuss these matters. This spring, he came to visit my mountain. My younger brother, Yankui, and I accompanied him to the peaks of Longjing, Guancheng Lake, Pipa, Yuntai, and Miaogu, where we bathed in raging currents and sat upon boulders, roaming as if with heaven itself, forgetting the world of men.

Yanhong then asked: "You once spoke of my name, 'The Pure One.' Now that I have had the honor of this journey, may I inquire into its meaning?" I pointed to the water and said to him: "Water is a tranquil thing. From deep sources and hidden ravines, it gathers in a single, limpid pool. Yet when it surges from its lair, leaping and tumbling through a hundred turns, it flows downward for thousands of miles—vast as rivers and seas, narrow as streams and valleys. It rages against rocks, howls in the wind. Though obstructed by thorns, it may be blocked; though fouled by filth, it may be muddied. Fish and dragons dwell in its depths, forests and trees shade its seclusion, wind and rain darken its moisture—nothing can impede its flow. Day and night, it never ceases, its momentum unstoppable, for this is the nature of its encounter.

Yet in its essence, it is inherently clear. Thorns cannot block it, filth cannot muddy it. It embraces all yet illuminates all—this is the work of primordial qi. The Dao’s principle of method originates in qi. Water flows between heaven and earth as qi flows within the body. In the space of a single breath, movement and stillness, fullness and emptiness, growth and decay are all present.

The human heart governs qi. Fundamentally pure and bright, its emptiness and luminosity are like a limpid pool. Yet when it pursues desire and is obscured, moved by external things, if one does not apply the effort to restrain and refine it, it becomes enslaved by the outer world, stumbling and entangled—like water surging from its lair, its momentum unstoppable. Its qi scatters into thoughts, emotions, and desires, becoming blocked and muddied as it should."

chunks.original_text: 是故圣贤训之，防闲其心，正以觉其误，复其流，使求犹水之所遭者使然。 其净明未尝捆焉，而昭昭者存，而谓之道行，而谓之法。 则周流六虚，与天地并行而不违者，发而为风雨雷霆，若固有之。 何哉？ 盖河洛二五之数，与雷霆三五之道，万有生息，一是本焉。 是以养之为至和，施之为至神，孚以荡磨，通以诚殷，则妙用之契，若返掌矣。 特有幽冥鬼神之异，彼所鲜言，吾兼用之也。 夫是必纯而后能一，一则性命之道备矣，尚何法云哉。 故观物之性，则知己之性，能尽己之性，则知天矣。 知夫天，则在我之天即彼天也。 感通之道，孰得而二焉。 故内修之士，多佯狂使酒，谈笑怒骂，皆可役风致雷，顾岂苟然哉。 彦宏既备究法奥纯一之功，熟习而尝验者也，尚何言乎。 且余闻其上世有闻道而超脱者，其好尚之笃，岂非宿习也哉。 彦宏勉之。 吁为侍宸王真君之邑里，尚振其遗传以启将来，是所望焉。 因请志之，遂笔於碉上。 志学说 学之大本，存乎性命，道德而已矣。 夫心统性情，而性禀天命之所赋也。 四时五行、庶类万化，莫不出乎命。 四端五典、万物万事，莫不具乎性。 然而万殊一本，其理未尝不一焉。 是以率之之谓道，修之之谓教，而必学而后知也。 其始乎孝悌忠信，成乎升降酬醉，无时而不学也。 经之谓学，肇於说命，日学於古训乃有获，念终始典於学，此圣人之学也。 圣贤知全乎天理之公，则清明纯粹之体具。 愚不肖惟溺乎人欲之私，晦浊邪僻之偏。 固学之者，求去其蔽，而复乎本有之善而已耳。 故必究夫尽性致命、明善诚身之道焉。 是以礼义为之品节防范，以言行为之涵养省察，然必隆师亲友而后得，则持敬以居之，由义以行之，久之入乎耳，着乎心，无入而不自得焉。 今夫造父善御，羿善射，师旷之律，捶之弓，奚仲之车，杜之乘，虽工仗之小，且犹志壳而后中焉。 蚓学也，圣贤之事乎。 夫子既圣矣，而不自圣，犹日：吾十有五而志於学。 当是时，以及千万世，岂有过圣矣乎。 而犹志乎学哉。 其设也，在唐虞曰成均，殷日太学，又日瞽宗。 周之太学为东郊，小学为虞庠，此汉唐所以发之也。 而唐虞之君皆圣矣，亦未始不师焉。 若尧学於君畴，舜学於务成昭，禹学於西王国，汤学於成子伯，文王学於时子思，武王学於郭叔，此性之身之，亦有发焉－。 夫子亦尝问礼於老氏，访乐於苌弘，问氏於刻子。 而孟轲学於子思之门，荀卿学於邹衍，此儒之所相传也。 但之为董韩，继之为濂洛，卒求乎中正仁义之归，而确乎其返身之谓也。 得乎六经之膏腴者，粹中阀外，足以参赞发育，而形诸至和者，着而为之文，经纬错综，托以载夫道焉。 是故衡璜瑭璃之仪，彝鼎笕篡之制，有不待饰，而知其为清庙之器也。 岂徒若怀窃鼓铸之流，夸浮文伪，惟雕虫刻镂以争妍取怜之是效也。 苟不能达乎正大高明之域，‘徒竞於青宇鬼顼之趋，若之何而谓之学哉。 必造其指，而底於成也。 视向之得夫师友者，不啻言之於堕括，陶之於涎坛，不劳力而有矣。 盖得诸己者，道之精微，学之渊密，充实光辉而日益其视。 锦绣纂组，不足谓之华，茵鼎圭绶，不足谓之荣。 是虽丝缕菽粟之薄，萧曹杯水之陋，不改其乐也乎。
chunks.translated_text:
Thus, the sages and worthies instruct us to guard and restrain the heart, precisely to awaken it from error, restore its flow, and make its seeking akin to water’s response to what it encounters. Its purity and luminosity are never truly lost; the radiance remains, and this is called the Dao in motion, the method in operation. Then, circulating through the six directions of emptiness, moving in harmony with heaven and earth without conflict, it manifests as wind, rain, thunder, and lightning—ever-present as if inherent. Why is this so? For the numerical patterns of the Yellow River and Luo River, the Way of thunder and lightning, and the ceaseless generation of the myriad beings all share a single origin. Thus, to cultivate it is to attain supreme harmony; to apply it is to achieve supreme divinity. Through sincerity, it polishes and refines; through earnest devotion, it penetrates and communicates. Then, the wondrous efficacy of its resonance is as effortless as turning one’s palm.

Yet there are subtle and mysterious workings of spirits and gods, rarely spoken of by others, which I also employ. This requires absolute purity to achieve unity; once unified, the Way of nature and destiny is complete—what further method could be needed? Therefore, by observing the nature of things, one knows one’s own nature; by fully realizing one’s own nature, one knows Heaven. Knowing Heaven, the Heaven within oneself is the same as that beyond. In the Way of resonance and communion, who can divide them into two?

Thus, those who cultivate inwardly often feign madness or indulge in wine, their laughter and rage alike capable of summoning wind and commanding thunder. Yet how could this be mere happenstance? Yan Hong has thoroughly investigated the profound subtleties of the method and the work of purity and unity, practicing and verifying it through experience—what more need be said? Moreover, I have heard that among his ancestors were those who attained the Dao and transcended the mundane. His deep devotion to this pursuit—could it not be the echo of past cultivation?

Yan Hong, take heed. As one who dwells in the same village as the Perfected Lord of the Celestial King’s Court, you must revive this legacy to enlighten future generations. This is my hope. At his request, I have inscribed these words upon the wall.

**On the Learning of the Great Foundation**
The great foundation of learning lies in nature and destiny, in the Dao and virtue alone. The heart governs nature and emotion, while nature is bestowed by the mandate of Heaven. The four seasons, five phases, and the transformations of the myriad beings all emerge from destiny. The four beginnings, five constants, and the ten thousand things and affairs all reside within nature. Yet though the myriad things differ, their principle is never not one. Thus, to follow it is called the Dao; to cultivate it is called teaching. Yet one must study to know it.

Learning begins with filial piety, brotherly respect, loyalty, and trust, and culminates in the rituals of ascent, descent, toasting, and drinking—there is no moment when one does not learn. The Classics call this learning. It originates in the *Shu Jing*, which states, *"Study the ancient teachings to gain insight,"* and *"Hold fast to the beginning and end, relying on learning."* This is the learning of the sages.

The sages and worthies, fully comprehending the impartiality of Heaven’s principle, possess a body of clarity, purity, and integrity. The foolish and unworthy, drowning in the selfishness of human desire, fall into obscurity, turbidity, and perversity. Thus, those who study seek to remove their obstructions and restore the inherent goodness within. Therefore, one must thoroughly investigate the Way of fully realizing nature and fulfilling destiny, of illuminating goodness and embodying sincerity.

Thus, ritual and righteousness serve as its standards and boundaries; speech and conduct are its means of nurturing and reflection. Yet one must honor teachers and befriend the virtuous to attain it. Abide in reverence, act in accordance with righteousness, and over time, it enters the ears, takes root in the heart, and permeates all without exception.

Consider this: Zaofu excelled in charioteering, Yi in archery, Shi Kuang in tuning, Zhui in bow-making, Xizhong in carriage-crafting, and Du in horsemanship. Even in such minor skills, they focused their intent before achieving mastery. How much more so for learning—the work of sages and worthies!

Confucius, though already a sage, did not consider himself one, saying, *"At fifteen, I set my heart on learning."* From that time to a thousand generations hence, who could surpass his sageliness? Yet he still dedicated himself to learning.

In ancient times, the institutions of learning took different names: in the Tang and Yu dynasties, it was called *Chengjun*; in the Yin, *Taixue* or *Guzong*; in the Zhou, *Taixue* was in the eastern suburbs, and the elementary school was called *Yuxiang*. The Han and Tang dynasties developed these further. Yet even the sage-kings of Tang and Yu never ceased to learn: Yao studied under Jun Chou, Shun under Wu Chengzhao, Yu under Xi Wangguo, Tang under Cheng Zibo, King Wen under Shi Zisi, and King Wu under Guo Shu. Even Confucius once inquired about ritual from Laozi, sought music from Chang Hong, and asked about the *Yi* from Xi Ze. Mencius studied under the disciples of Zisi, and Xunzi under Zou Yan. This is the transmission of the Confucians.

Later, Dong Zhongshu and Han Yu continued this lineage, ultimately seeking the return to the mean, uprightness, benevolence, and righteousness, firmly rooted in self-cultivation. Those who draw from the rich essence of the Six Classics, refined within and flourishing without, are capable of assisting in the generation and nurturing of all things, manifesting the supreme harmony. This is expressed in writing, weaving together the warp and weft to bear the Dao.

Thus, the instruments of *heng*, *huang*, *tang*, and *li*, the vessels of *yi*, *ding*, *jian*, and *guan*—without adornment, one knows they are the sacred implements of the ancestral temple. How could they be compared to those who, like thieves of bronze and iron, boast of empty embellishments, competing in ornate carvings and trivial decorations to curry favor?

If one cannot reach the realm of uprightness, grandeur, and luminosity, but merely vies in the petty and trivial, how can this be called learning? One must grasp its essence and attain completion. Compared to those who gain from teachers and friends, it is as if one had merely memorized formulas or molded clay—achieving nothing without effort.

For what is gained from within—the subtleties of the Dao, the profundity of learning—fills and illuminates, daily expanding one’s vision. Brocade and embroidery cannot be called splendor; mats, tripods, jade tablets, and sashes cannot be called honor. Even the humblest of silk threads or grains of millet, the simplest of cups or plainest of water, do not diminish the joy of one who has attained this.

chunks.original_text: 抑亦一毫不足累其中而然哉。 然而麒骥一跃，不能十步，驽马十驾，功在不舍。 然其所至虽有疾徐之异，在乎息与不息哉。 斯其圣人志而不厌也欤。 余犹子某，纯敏嗜学，尝以伯氏某，扁其进修之所日志学，请一言申其义。 余之於学也，探蹊而未入于闽者也，其能有以启之乎。 某尚勉之，使其习之至行之着，余将见其所成，立诅可量哉。 是为说以俟。 紫虚元君传 元君姓魏氏，讳华存，字贤安，任城人。 晋司徒舒之女也，魏齐王嘉平三年辛未生。 天质卓异，少读老庄言，即慕道，嗜闲居独处。 年二十有四，父母强适南阳刘文，字幼彦。 生二子璞、遐。 幼彦为汲郡修武令。 二子粗立，乃斋心别柄，绝饮食，反修初服。 太康九年戊申十二月十又六日夜半，感太极真人、青童道君、扶桑旸谷神王、景林真人、清虚真人来降。 谓元君曰：闻子密纬真气，太帝君劫我授子神真之道。 遂出太上宝文《八素隐书》、《大洞真经》、《高仙羽玄》等书三十一卷，授元君日：是书昔授之西城总真君，今以付子。 且语以存思、指归之诀乃去。 元君时年三十有七。 咸和九年甲午、清虚青童君复降，与药二剂，使旋服之，克期会洛阳宫。 是月七日夜半，太乙遣台车来迎，元君用藏景之道，托形神剑而化，享年八十有三。 遂往阳洛山。 明日青童君、太极四真人、清虚王君再降，会元君於隐洞云台，众真各标至训，三日而去。 元君积诵玉书，颜如少女。 於是西王母、南极元君来迎，〔登〕晨诣上清宫玉阙，玉宸大道君、太微天帝、金阙后圣君，各致命授以玉札金文，位为紫虚元君，领南岳上真司命，秩比仙公，使治天台、大霍山洞台之中，主下教学仙者。 次司命神仙，请隶属南岳。 诸真乃与元君俱诣天台、大霍山洞台，道过句曲金坛，茅君叔申燕会二日夕，乃共适霍山矣。 兴定二年乙丑六月二十三日，元君与众真降句曲金坛杨羲家，华阳之传始此，是为上清第一代宗师。 宋元佑问，进封高元宸照紫虚至道元君云。 金野庵传 金蓬头，永嘉人也。 名志阳，号野庵，因蓬首中作一髻，世呼蓬头。 云生故姓家，乡井德之。 幼果敢，有大志不羁。 甫长，知慕道弃世虑，遂师全真李月溪。 月溪，白紫清徒也。 一见器之，命游燕、赵、齐、楚求正焉。 及参先德李真常，益有省。

Yet is this not because even the slightest hindrance could burden one’s heart? Still, the swiftest steed cannot cover ten paces in a single leap, while the slowest horse, through tenfold perseverance, achieves success by never abandoning the effort. Though their destinations may differ in speed, the distinction lies in whether one ceases or persists. Such is the unwearying resolve of the sage.

My young nephew, so-and-so, is of pure and keen disposition, devoted to learning. He once asked his elder brother, so-and-so, to name his study "Daily Progress in Learning" and requested a few words to expound its meaning. As for my own learning, I have merely explored the byways without entering the gate—how could I presume to enlighten him? Yet I urge him to strive on, so that his practice becomes consummate and his conduct illustrious. Then I shall witness his accomplishments, which shall be boundless and immeasurable. This is my explanation, offered in anticipation.

---

**The Transmission of Lady Zixu, the Primordial Sovereign**

The Primordial Sovereign was surnamed Wei, named Huacun, styled Xian’an, and was a native of Rencheng. She was the daughter of Wei Shu, Minister of Works during the Jin dynasty, and was born in the third year of the Jiaping reign of King Qi of Wei (251 CE). Of extraordinary natural endowment, she read the words of Laozi and Zhuangzi in her youth and soon came to revere the Dao, delighting in seclusion and solitude. At the age of twenty-four, her parents compelled her to marry Liu Wen of Nanyang, styled Youyan, by whom she bore two sons, Pu and Xia. Youyan served as Magistrate of Xiuwu in Jijun. Once her two sons were grown, she purified her heart, withdrew to a separate chamber, abstained from food and drink, and resumed her original practice.

On the night of the sixteenth day of the twelfth month of the ninth year of the Taikang reign (288 CE), the Perfected of the Supreme Ultimate, the Lord of the Azure Lads, the Divine King of Fusang’s Yang Valley, the Perfected of Jinglin, and the Perfected of Qingxu descended and addressed the Primordial Sovereign: "Having heard of your secret cultivation of true qi, the Supreme Emperor has commanded us to transmit to you the Way of the Divine Perfected." Thereupon, they presented thirty-one scrolls, including the *Treasure Writ of the Supreme Lord*, the *Hidden Book of the Eight Simplicities*, the *Perfect Scripture of the Great Cavern*, and the *Mysteries of the Lofty Immortals*, saying: "These texts were once bestowed upon the Lord of Total Perfection of the Western City; now we entrust them to you." They also instructed her in the secrets of visualization and the essentials of return before departing. At that time, the Primordial Sovereign was thirty-seven years old.

In the ninth year of the Xianhe reign (334 CE), the Lord of Qingxu and the Azure Lads descended again, presenting her with two doses of elixir and commanding her to ingest them in preparation for a meeting at the Palace of Luoyang at an appointed time. On the night of the seventh day of that month, the Supreme Unity dispatched a terrace chariot to welcome her. Employing the Way of Concealed Radiance, the Primordial Sovereign entrusted her form to the divine sword and transformed, having lived eighty-three years. She then proceeded to Yangluo Mountain.

The following day, the Lord of Qingxu, the Four Perfected of the Supreme Ultimate, and the Divine King of Qingxu descended once more, meeting the Primordial Sovereign at the Cloud Terrace of the Hidden Grotto. Each Perfected imparted their ultimate teachings, and after three days, they departed. The Primordial Sovereign had recited the Jade Scriptures so extensively that her complexion remained that of a young maiden. Thereupon, the Queen Mother of the West and the Primordial Sovereign of the Southern Culmen came to welcome her. Ascending at dawn to the Jade Tower of the Palace of Supreme Clarity, the Great Dao Lord of the Jade Dawn, the Celestial Emperor of the Grand Tenuity, and the Later Sage Lord of the Golden Watchtower each issued decrees, bestowing upon her jade tablets and golden writs. She was invested as the Primordial Sovereign of Zixu, charged with overseeing the life-destinies of the Upper Perfected of the Southern Marchmount, her rank equivalent to that of an Immortal Duke. She was further entrusted with governance of the Central Terrace of Tiantai and the Great Huo Mountain, where she would instruct those who sought immortality. The Perfected of the Life-Destiny Office of the Immortals were placed under her jurisdiction in the Southern Marchmount.

The various Perfected then accompanied the Primordial Sovereign to Tiantai and the Central Terrace of the Great Huo Mountain. Passing through Jinqu’s Golden Altar, they were hosted by the Mao Lords, Shu and Shen, for a two-day feast before proceeding to Huo Mountain.

On the twenty-third day of the sixth month of the second year of the Xingding reign (1219 CE), the Primordial Sovereign and the host of Perfected descended to the Golden Altar of Jinqu at the home of Yang Xi, marking the beginning of the Huayang transmission. Thus, she became the first patriarch of the Supreme Clarity lineage. During the Yuanyou reign of the Song dynasty, she was posthumously enfeoffed as the Primordial Sovereign of Zixu, the Illustrious and Profound Dao of the Supreme Mystery.

---

**The Transmission of Jin Ye’an**

Jin Pengtou, a native of Yongjia, was named Zhiyang and styled Ye’an. His unkempt hair, gathered into a single topknot, earned him the sobriquet "Pengtou" ("Disheveled Head"). Born into a family of virtuous repute in his hometown, he was resolute and daring from childhood, possessing great aspirations and an untamed spirit. As he matured, he came to yearn for the Dao and relinquished worldly concerns, becoming a disciple of Li Yuexi of the Quanzhen tradition. Yuexi, a disciple of Bai Ziqing, recognized his potential upon their first meeting and dispatched him to travel through Yan, Zhao, Qi, and Chu in search of true teachings. Later, upon studying with the eminent master Li Zhenchang, he gained even deeper insight.

chunks.original_text: 行经袁州，遇守城校尉颠军子，状貌伟素，日不与世接，夜宿神祠问，蓬头异而师之。 既久，语益有得。 时紫山邹廷佐慕道，建长春观礼之。 未几，命其徒刘志玄典观事，乃游武夷、龙虎二山。 时龙虎主先天观者傅师正，馆于蓬莱庵，庵墟征君、圣井、藐姑诸峰之会。 蓬头攀陆崖壑，倡鹿豕、藉云雾，视以为常。 问夜坐盘石，蛇虎值於前，辄愕而遁去。 因得夷旷地，命其徒李全正、赵真纯，筑天瑞庵于峰顶。 时四方闻其道着，无远近有疾患辄叩之，以所供果服之无不验，由是礼者日集。 尝天旱叩龙井，召龙出语，龙出听，瑜时渐小，跃入袖中，乃警以愒，龙腾奋入水，未顷天雨。 元统癸酉，复隐武夷山，居紫清之止止庵。 浙束元帅李太平闻而礼之，谓日：命严则君治，心清则虑寡。 李益敬叹。 及叛贼李志甫寇漳州，国朝以其地同知昊公知寇道，命为先锋平之，其子仲良愿师事之，不许。 随果夷灭。 众神服或倦请谒者众，谋药死之，即预知，命徒凿窍地中，果服出之，今名吐丹井云。 至元正月一日，同辈桂心渊，世称桂风子，坐解于庐山，旋闻之。 於四月十日，命徒书愒，坐逝。 越十三日，面俯若栗，肢体温软犹生。 其徒座于庵侧之古梅下。 生前至元丙子五月四日。 高弟则劳衍素、郭处常、李西来、殷破纳、方方壶，皆以道法闻世云。 芒苗子日：古之烈夫义士，必苦行洁身，以成其志，故其视裂肌肤，摧筋力，若所固然，是以其卓绝特立，足以垂示千载。 若金蓬头是也。 然欲立名於世，且必是而后可，况其超脱幻化者哉。 求能若此，而於道无成焉，未有也。 惜能是者，代亦几人哉。 赵原阳传 赵原阳，名宜真，吉之安福人也。 其先家浚仪，宋燕王德昭十三世孙某，仕元为安福令，因家焉。 原阳幼颖敏，知读书，即善习诵，博通经史百家言，长习进士业。 未几试于京，以病不果赴。 久不愈，夜梦神人曰：汝吾道人，何望世贵。 父遂命从道，已而笃嗜恬淡。 学益进。
chunks.translated_text:
Passing through Yuanzhou, he encountered Dian Junzi, a garrison commander of imposing yet unadorned appearance, who shunned worldly company by day and lodged in spirit shrines by night. Ye’an, struck by his singularity, took him as his master. With time, their exchanges yielded ever deeper understanding.

At that time, Zou Tingsuo of Zishan, an admirer of the Dao, built the Changchun Abbey and paid homage to him. Shortly after, he entrusted the abbey’s affairs to his disciple Liu Zhixuan and journeyed to the two sacred mountains of Wuyi and Longhu. There, Fu Shizheng, the master of the Xiantian Abbey on Longhu Mountain, lodged him at Penglai Hermitage, situated at the confluence of the ruins of the Recluse, the Sacred Well, and Miaogu Peaks. Ye’an scaled cliffs and ravines, mingled with deer and boars, and slept amidst clouds and mist as though it were ordinary. By night, he would sit upon a boulder, and when serpents or tigers appeared before him, they would startle and flee. Thus he came upon a level, open expanse, where he commanded his disciples Li Quanzheng and Zhao Zhenchun to construct Tianrui Hermitage atop the peak.

As his reputation for the Dao spread, people from near and far afflicted by illness sought him out. Whatever fruits he offered them proved efficacious without fail, and so those who came to pay their respects grew daily. Once, during a drought, he knocked upon the Dragon Well and summoned the dragon forth. The dragon emerged to listen, its form gradually diminishing until it leapt into his sleeve. He admonished it sternly, whereupon the dragon surged back into the water, and rain fell before long.

In the *guiyou* year of the Yuantong era (1333), he withdrew once more to Wuyi Mountain, residing at the Zhizhi Hermitage of Ziqing. Li Taiping, the Yuan Marshal of Zhedong, heard of him and paid him homage, saying: "When commands are strict, the lord governs; when the mind is clear, cares diminish." Li was all the more filled with reverence and admiration.

When the rebel Li Zhifu invaded Zhangzhou, the imperial court appointed Prefect Wu to oversee the suppression of the bandits and named him vanguard commander. Wu’s son, Zhongliang, wished to become Ye’an’s disciple, but he refused. Soon after, the rebels were indeed vanquished. As the throng of spirits and deities grew weary of the constant petitioners, they plotted to poison him. Foreknowing this, he ordered his disciples to dig a pit in the earth, whereupon the poison was expelled. The site is now called the Elixir-Vomiting Well.

On the first day of the first month of the *zhi-yuan* era (1335), his fellow adept Gui Xinyuan—known in the world as Gui Fengzi—attained liberation while seated at Mount Lu. Ye’an soon learned of this. On the tenth day of the fourth month, he instructed his disciples to record his final admonitions and passed away in meditation. Thirteen days later, his face remained as though flushed, and his limbs retained their warmth and suppleness as in life. His disciples interred him beneath an ancient plum tree beside the hermitage.

He was born on the fourth day of the fifth month of the *bingzi* year of the Zhiyuan era (1276). His foremost disciples—Lao Yansu, Guo Chuchang, Li Xilai, Yin Pona, and Fang Fanghu—all became renowned in the world for their mastery of the Dao.

Mang Miaozi remarked: "The resolute men and righteous knights of old invariably endured hardship and purified themselves to fulfill their aspirations. Thus they regarded the rending of flesh and the breaking of sinew as matters of course, and by their towering singularity, they left examples for a thousand generations. Such was Jin Pengtou. Yet if one seeks to establish a name in the world, one must first attain such resolve—how much more so for those who transcend illusion and transformation? Those capable of such attainment yet failing to achieve the Dao are unheard of. Alas, how few in any age have been capable of this!"

---

**The Transmission of Zhao Yuanyang**

Zhao Yuanyang, whose given name was Yizhen, was a native of Anfu in Ji Prefecture. His ancestors hailed from Junyi, and he was a thirteenth-generation descendant of Zhao Dezhao, the Prince of Yan during the Song Dynasty. His forebear served as magistrate of Anfu under the Yuan and settled there. Yuanyang was precocious in childhood, quick to learn, and adept at recitation. He mastered the classics, histories, and the writings of the Hundred Schools, and in his youth pursued the path of the imperial examinations. Soon after, he sat for the metropolitan examination but withdrew due to illness. His condition persisted, and one night he dreamed of a divine figure who said: "You are a man of my Dao—why do you seek worldly eminence?" His father then directed him toward the Dao, and thereafter he became deeply devoted to tranquility and detachment. His learning advanced ever further.

chunks.original_text: 初师郡之有道者，日曾尘外，嗣诸法要，问有缺文，必考述尽详。 复师吉之泰宇观张天全，别号铁玄张，师龙虎山金野庵，得金液内外丹诀。 后复师南昌李玄一，玄一荐之师蒲衣冯先生，冯亦师野庵。 云尝游白鹤山永兴观，乃西晋匡仙故迹，遂居。 问以所授致雷雨、度精爽，皆有异感，闻者越千里走从之会。 壬辰兵兴，挟弟子西游吴蜀，暨还游武当，谒龙虎，访汉天师遗迹。 时天师冲虚公深嘉礼之，欲留不可，宫之学者多师焉。 还至赣之雩都紫阳观，因居焉。 凡道门旨奥，皆缀辑成书。 或为诗歌以自警，犹以医济人，且绝交处，寡言笑，闻者愿礼不获。 其高行伟操，为时所推慕，从游者益众。 岁壬戌正月朔，谢众日：吾将逝矣，自今日始，钥静关，慎无有干。 迨五月三日夏至，启关，祝弟子善自立，漱浴更衣趺坐。 适县导诏至乐呜，即书愒，掷笔而化，雷电骤作，白昼晦冥。 明日，官庶瞻敬者群至，门命游燕、赵、齐、楚求正焉。 及参先德李真常，益有省。

At first, he studied under a man of the Dao in his commandery, one Zeng Chenwai, and inherited the essential teachings. Where texts were incomplete, he would invariably seek out and verify them in exhaustive detail. Later, he became a disciple of Zhang Tianquan of Taiyu Abbey in Ji, also known as Iron Mystery Zhang, who had himself studied under Jin Yea of Mount Longhu and received the oral instructions for the inner and outer elixirs of golden fluid. Subsequently, he studied under Li Xuanyi of Nanchang, who recommended him to his own master, Master Feng of the Robes of Rushes, who had also been a disciple of Yea. It was said that he once traveled to Yongxing Abbey on White Crane Mountain, the former site of the immortal Kuang of the Western Jin, and took up residence there. When asked about the methods he had been taught for summoning thunder and rain or refining the essence-spirit, he invariably elicited extraordinary responses, and those who heard of him would travel a thousand *li* to seek his instruction.

In the year *renchen*, as war broke out, he journeyed west to Wu and Shu with his disciples, and upon his return, he traveled to Mount Wudang, visited Mount Longhu, and sought out the vestiges of the Celestial Master of Han. At that time, the Celestial Master Chongxu deeply admired and honored him, wishing to detain him, but he declined. Many of the abbey’s scholars then became his disciples. On his return, he stayed at Ziyang Abbey in Yudu of Ganzhou and settled there. He compiled all the profound principles of the Daoist canon into written works. At times, he composed poems and songs to admonish himself, while also using medicine to aid others. In seclusion, he spoke little and laughed seldom, yet those who heard of him longed to pay him homage, though few were granted the opportunity. His lofty conduct and noble character were revered and admired by his contemporaries, and his followers grew ever more numerous.

In the first month of the year *rentu*, on the first day of the new year, he addressed his disciples, saying: “I shall soon depart. Thunder and lightning suddenly erupted, and the daylight turned to darkness. The following day, officials and commoners who came to pay their respects gathered in great numbers. His disciples were dispatched to the regions of Yan, Zhao, Qi, and Chu to seek further instruction. When they consulted the former virtuous Li Zhenchang, they gained even deeper insight.

chunks.original_text: 行经袁州，遇守城校尉颠军子，状貌伟素，日不与世接，夜宿神祠问，蓬头异而师之。 既久，语益有得。 时紫山邹廷佐慕道，建长春观礼之。 未几，命其徒刘志玄典观事，乃游武夷、龙虎二山。 时龙虎主先天观者傅师正，馆于蓬莱庵，庵墟征君、圣井、藐姑诸峰之会。 蓬头攀陆崖壑，倡鹿豕、藉云雾，视以为常。 问夜坐盘石，蛇虎值於前，辄愕而遁去。 因得夷旷地，命其徒李全正、赵真纯，筑天瑞庵于峰顶。 时四方闻其道着，无远近有疾患辄叩之，以所供果服之无不验，由是礼者日集。 尝天旱叩龙井，召龙出语，龙出听，瑜时渐小，跃入袖中，乃警以愒，龙腾奋入水，未顷天雨。 元统癸酉，复隐武夷山，居紫清之止止庵。 浙束元帅李太平闻而礼之，谓日：命严则君治，心清则虑寡。 李益敬叹。 及叛贼李志甫寇漳州，国朝以其地同知昊公知寇道，命为先锋平之，其子仲良愿师事之，不许。 随果夷灭。 众神服或倦请谒者众，谋药死之，即预知，命徒凿窍地中，果服出之，今名吐丹井云。 至元正月一日，同辈桂心渊，世称桂风子，坐解于庐山，旋闻之。 於四月十日，命徒书愒，坐逝。 越十三日，面俯若栗，肢体温软犹生。 其徒座于庵侧之古梅下。 生前至元丙子五月四日。 高弟则劳衍素、郭处常、李西来、殷破纳、方方壶，皆以道法闻世云。 芒苗子日：古之烈夫义士，必苦行洁身，以成其志，故其视裂肌肤，摧筋力，若所固然，是以其卓绝特立，足以垂示千载。 若金蓬头是也。 然欲立名於世，且必是而后可，况其超脱幻化者哉。 求能若此，而於道无成焉，未有也。 惜能是者，代亦几人哉。 赵原阳传 赵原阳，名宜真，吉之安福人也。 其先家浚仪，宋燕王德昭十三世孙某，仕元为安福令，因家焉。 原阳幼颖敏，知读书，即善习诵，博通经史百家言，长习进士业。 未几试于京，以病不果赴。 久不愈，夜梦神人曰：汝吾道人，何望世贵。 父遂命从道，已而笃嗜恬淡。 学益进。
